description: A problem-solving principle that the simplest solution tends to be the right one
A philosophy suggesting that actions resulting in negative outcomes are more often caused by ignorance or negligence than malice
A cognitive bias in which low-ability individuals overestimate their ability
The mental discomfort experienced by a person who holds two or more contradictory beliefs or values
The tendency to search for, interpret, favor, and recall information that confirms or supports one's prior beliefs or values
A mistake in reasoning where a decision is influenced by what has already been invested
The cost of forgoing the next best alternative when making a decision
An economic theory that predicts that after some optimal level of capacity is reached, additional input will not produce proportionate increases in output
A mode of inquiry that relentlessly pursues the foundations of a problem or reality

concept: The Map is Not the Territory
description: An idea that an individual's perception of reality is not the same as reality itself
A process where the value of an investment increases because the earnings on an investment, both capital gains and interest, earn interest as time passes
A theoretical situation where individuals don't cooperate even though it seems that it would be in their best interest to do so
A statistical concept that states that if a variable is extreme the first time you measure it, it will be closer to the average the next time you measure it
A type of reactivity in which individuals modify an aspect of their behavior in response to their awareness of being observed
The phenomenon whereby as more people or users join a platform, the value of the platform to those users increases
A logical error of concentrating on the people or things that made it past some selection process and overlooking those that did not
A mathematical formula used for calculating conditional probabilities
An observation that for many outcomes, roughly 80% of consequences come from 20% of causes
A type of probability distribution that is symmetric about the mean, showing that data near the mean are more frequent in occurrence than data far from the mean
An observation that the tendency in most organizational hierarchies is for every employee to rise in the hierarchy through promotion until they reach a level of respective incompetence
A thinking approach where one considers what one wants to avoid instead of what they want to achieve
A logical fallacy that states 'Since event Y followed event X, event Y must have been caused by event X'
The tendency people have to overemphasize personal characteristics and ignore situational factors in judging others' behavior

A situation in a shared-resource system where individual users acting independently according to their own self-interest behave contrary to the common good of all users by depleting or spoiling the resources through their collective action

A hypothesis that organisms must constantly adapt, evolve, and proliferate not merely to gain reproductive advantage, but also simply to survive while pitted against ever-evolving opposing organisms in an ever-changing environment
A situation in which one party gets involved in a risky event knowing that it is protected against the risk and the other party will incur the cost
A cognitive bias where an individual relies too heavily on an initial piece of information offered to make subsequent judgments during decision making
The phenomenon whereby a minute localized change in a complex system can have large effects elsewhere
The tendency for an impression created in one area to influence opinion in another area
A cognitive bias in which people tend to underestimate the variability of small samples
A situation in which one person's gain is equivalent to another's loss, meaning the net change in wealth or benefit is zero
The number of transistors on a microchip will double approximately every two years, leading to an exponential increase in computing power
A time management tool that helps prioritize tasks by urgency and importance
A form of disciplined questioning that can be used to pursue thought in many directions and for many purposes
A phenomenon whereby an attempt to hide, remove, or censor a piece of information has the unintended consequence of publicizing the information more widely
The future life expectancy of a non-perishable thing like a technology or an idea is proportional to its current age
A solution that people will tend to use in the absence of communication, because it seems natural, special, or relevant to them
A concept that suggests 'the rich get richer and the poor get poorer' or those who already have will receive more
A mental shortcut that relies on immediate examples that come to mind when evaluating a specific topic, concept, method, or decision
The idea that the pain of losing is psychologically twice as powerful as the pleasure of gaining
When multiple cognitive biases, tendencies or mental models act in the same direction, they compound to produce irrational, often exceedingly foolish behavior
The act of trying to make things efficient in a stage where it is not yet clear what would be the best way to do so
A suggested cognitive limit to the number of people with whom one can maintain stable social relationships
A criminological theory that states that visible signs of crime, anti-social behavior, and civil disorder create an urban environment that encourages further crime and disorder
The tendency for people to place a disproportionately high value on products they partially created
The phenomenon whereby higher expectations lead to an increase in performance
A monetary principle stating that 'bad money drives out good'
A concept that if a variable is extreme on its first measurement, it will tend to be closer to the average on its second measurement
An area of mathematics looking at systems that are highly sensitive to initial conditions
An adage that 'anything that can go wrong, will go wrong'
A behavioral economic theory suggesting that individuals make decisions based on the potential value of losses and gains rather than the final outcome
A tendency for people to prefer smaller, immediate payoffs over larger, later payoffs
The observed tendency of humans to quickly return to a relatively stable level of happiness despite major positive or negative events or life changes
An adage that 'work expands so as to fill the time available for its completion'
A theorem that describes the result of performing the same experiment a large number of times
A cognitive bias where people decide on options based on whether the options are presented with positive or negative semantics
A perceived idea after an event has occurred that the event was predictable, despite there being little or no objective basis for predicting it
A social psychological phenomenon in which individuals are less likely to offer help to a victim when other people are present
A social norm of responding to a positive action with another positive action, rewarding kind actions
The economic theory in which a limited supply of a good, coupled with a high demand for that good, results in a mismatch between the desired supply and demand equilibrium
A theory that seeks to explain how, why, and at what rate new ideas and technology spread

A business strategy that allows companies to realize significant profit out of selling low volumes of hard-to-find items to many customers instead of only selling large volumes of a reduced number of popular items
A philosophy suggesting that positive or negative thoughts bring positive or negative experiences into a person's life
An adage stating that organizations design systems which mirror their own communication structure

A legal and economic theory that affirms that where there are complete competitive markets with no transactions costs, an efficient set of inputs and outputs to and from production-optimal distribution are selected, regardless of how property rights are divided
An observation about software project management according to which 'adding human resources to a late software project makes it later'
A visual explanation of a design process, divided into four distinct phases, Discover, Define, Develop and Deliver

A problem in combinatorial optimization: Given a set of items, each with a weight and a value, determine the number of each item to include in a collection so that the total weight is less than or equal to a given limit and the total value is as large as possible
A concept in economics that states: 'When a measure becomes a target, it ceases to be a good measure'
A fundamental theory in quantum mechanics that places an absolute, theoretical limit on the combined accuracy of certain pairs of simultaneous, related measurements
A term used to illustrate the causes of incorrect stimulation in economy and politics
A phenomenon in probability and statistics, in which a trend appears in different groups of data but disappears or reverses when these groups are combined
The smallest amount of fissile material needed for a sustained nuclear chain reaction

The observation that as technological improvements increase the efficiency with which a resource is used
The Pareto Frontier,"A state of allocation of resources from which it is impossible to move without making someone worse off
An observation that states 'ninety percent of everything is crap'
A cognitive bias where individuals overestimate the level of agreement they have with others
The tendency to ignore dangerous or negative information by 'burying' one's head in the sand, like an ostrich
Taking a big picture view of a situation or problem, often to understand different perspectives
A change in frequency or wavelength of a wave in relation to an observer who is moving relative to the wave source
A situation in which the cost of producing one unit of a good or service decreases as the volume of production increases
A concept in game theory where the optimal outcome of a game is one where no player has an incentive to deviate from their chosen strategy after considering an opponent's choice
A mental model used to quickly learn new topics by explaining them in plain, simple language
The idea in chaos theory that a very small difference in the initial state of a physical system can make a significant difference to the state at some later time
The hypothesis that people might increase risky behavior as a response to safety regulations
The concept that considers the extreme impact of rare and unpredictable outlier events — and the human tendency to find simplistic explanations for these events, retrospectively

The idea that when individuals make decisions, their rationality is limited by the information they have, the cognitive limitations of their minds, and the finite amount of time they have to make decisions
The observation that each generation has a significantly higher IQ than the last
A model that describes the relationship between systematic risk and expected return for assets, particularly stocks
A cognitive bias where individuals ascribe more value to things merely because they own them

A common psychological phenomenon whereby individuals will give high accuracy ratings to descriptions of their personality that supposedly are tailored specifically for them, but are, in fact, vague and general enough to apply to a wide range of people
A method to cause a reflex response or behavior by training with repetitive action
The observation that 'it always takes longer than you expect, even when you take into account Hofstadter's Law'
A habit that people form that tend to lead to the development of other good habits
Learning by watching others, replicating their actions, and learning from the outcomes
A logical fallacy in which the reasoner begins with what they are trying to end with
